title: Shooters Island
text:
Shooters Island is a uninhabited island at the southern end of <a href="Newark%20Bay">Newark Bay</a>, off the <a href="North%20Shore%2C%20Staten%20Island">North Shore</a> of <a href="Staten%20Island">Staten Island</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. The boundary between the states of <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> and <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> runs through the island, with a small portion on the north end of the island belonging to the cities of <a href="Bayonne%2C%20New%20Jersey">Bayonne</a> and <a href="Elizabeth%2C%20New%20Jersey">Elizabeth</a> in New Jersey and the rest being part of the borough of Staten Island in New York City.
Early history.
In colonial times Shooters Island was used as a hunting preserve. During the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">Revolutionary War</a>, <a href="George%20Washington">George Washington</a> used the island as a <a href="dead%20drop">drop-off point</a> for messages, and the place became a haven for spies.
Shipyard.
The first shipyard on Shooters Island was created in 1860 by David Decker. From 1898 until 1910, the island was home to a major shipyard, the Townsend-Downey Shipbuilding Company. <a href="Theodore%20E.%20Ferris">Theodore E. Ferris</a>, who later designed the eponymous ships used by the American government in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, was an employee of the firm. Around this time it was also home to the Standard Shipbuilding Company, which bought the island in 1915. The entire island was occupied by buildings, including a foundry, pattern shop, and offices. There were major docks and shipways that faced to the east. Contrary to a previous report, President <a href="Theodore%20Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> did not go hunting on this industrial island.
The Townsend-Downey Company built a yacht, , for <a href="Wilhelm%20II%2C%20German%20Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm II</a> of Germany. Its launch in February 1902 was attended by many hundreds of spectators, including Pres. Theodore Roosevelt and <a href="Prince%20Henry%20of%20Prussia%20%281862%E2%80%931929%29">Prince Henry of Prussia</a>. <a href="Alice%20Roosevelt%20Longworth">Alice Roosevelt</a>, the president's daughter, christened the boat. <a href="Thomas%20Alva%20Edison">Thomas Alva Edison</a> sent a cameraman who made one of the first <a href="newsreel">news movies</a> of the event. It is available online from the Library of Congress. The next day a reception was held at the <a href="White%20House">White House</a> for Mr. Downey and representatives of the German Government.
The following year the fast three-masted <a href="schooner">schooner</a> was launched at the yard. In 1905, it raced across the Atlantic and won the Kaiser's cup and set a record for the crossing under sail which stood unbroken for almost 90 years. Another famous vessel built on Shooter's Island was , built for the Carnegie Institution of Washington for use in magnetic surveys in the Pacific Ocean. The brigantine yacht was named after industrialist and philanthropist <a href="Andrew%20Carnegie">Andrew Carnegie</a>, who was a friend of Mr. Downey. It was built entirely of wood and nonmagnetic metals so as not to interfere with magnetic measurements.
The island came under the control of the <a href="Tidewater%20Oil%20Company">Tidewater Oil Company</a> in 1903. In 1905, the eight building plant and its 33 acres were purchased by the <a href="Colonial%20Trust%20Company">Colonial Trust Company</a> for $516,000. At the time, the shipyard was valued at two million dollars.
The island was used for industrial and shipbuilding operations through 1922. Abandoned vessels began to accumulate around the perimeter of the island by 1930.
Bird sanctuary.
Neglected during much of the later 20th century, the island has been made an official <a href="bird%20sanctuary">bird sanctuary</a>, partially to discourage the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Corps%20of%20Engineers">United States Army Corps of Engineers</a> who wanted to blow up the island to ease navigation by vessels coming down from Port Newark. It has begun to disintegrate into Newark Bay. The island and decayed remnants of old piers are visible to users of the <a href="Bayonne%20Bridge">Bayonne Bridge</a> between Staten Island and <a href="Bayonne%2C%20New%20Jersey">Bayonne, New Jersey</a>. The remains of the once active shipyard are still present, but diminishing every year.
Shooters Island began to support nesting <a href="wading%20birds">wading birds</a>, <a href="cormorants">cormorants</a> and <a href="gulls">gulls</a> in the early 1970s. At its peak in 1995, the island supported 400 nesting pairs of <a href="herons">herons</a>, <a href="egrets">egrets</a>, <a href="ibis">ibis</a> and 121 nesting pairs of double-crested <a href="cormorants">cormorants</a>. The island is now owned by the <a href="New%20York%20City">City of New York</a> and is maintained by <a href="New%20York%20City%20Department%20of%20Parks%20and%20Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a> as a bird sanctuary.
